Cherry-picking a single best population, one of many. NOT creating a 
popul=
ation composed of best individuals from multiple populations. 
Though that =
could be a next step.

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Daniel Tuohy" <danielr=
2e@...> wrote:
>
> Cherry-picking the most-fit solutions from a random set =
of initial
> solutions seems equivalent to bootstrapping NEAT with random s=
earch.
> Random search is inferior to genetic search for most domains to 
w=
hich
> you would apply NEAT, so intuitively I would think that you wouldn't=

> see a tangible benefit from this approach.  In fact, you could be
> intr=
oducing damaging sampling bias by pointing NEAT away from optima
> that mig=
ht be too small to hit with the initial population, but may 
be
> reachable=
 from initial low-fit individuals.
> 
> My guess is that you won't do any h=
arm, but nor will you see
> improvement.  It's easy enough to test, though,=
 so give it a shot.  
My
> intuitions are wrong often enough.
>

, 2008 6:45 PM, afcarl2 <a.carl@...> wrote:

y significance to the composition of generation zero

the composition is a set of random points in the design

opulation/set of random starting points any

except for perhaps getting lucky in regards to a

ial via complexification?

ed on transition to

 wrt generation zero,

his is the case, is there any loss of generality by generating

pulation to proceed with NEAT evolution?
